bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1940

div1.p: Moran writes that he has information from the Rojas family on Army contracts for the occupation of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1940
div1.opener:
VIA AIR MAIL
Havana, Oct. 3, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
You will hang me, I am sure, just as soon as you can lay
hands on me. For the photographs, I have had all kinds of “contra-
tiempos”. I had to make two extra trips to have the photos taken,
having been caught in the rain twice. At that, they are not extra
good anyway, but hope they will serve your purpose.

Miss Rojas just called me on the phone to inform me that
she had some startling news for me. She said she found some contracts
covering the occupation of part of the “Finca San José” for Camp Lazear.
Am going to hot foot it out to the “Quinta San José” just as soon as
I get a bite of lunch. The Rojas family have been summering at the
“Quinta” for some months. Will let you know by tomorrow's airmail
what the evidence and dope is. I pray and hope it will lead to some-
thing conclusive. I also hope it will upset most of our calculations
for I am not at all sure of mine and have but little confidence in the
calculations (joint) of Doña Maria Teresa Loma Viuda de Rojas and MY
OWN SELF. The place is excavated so badly and honeycombed from so
many directions, in addition to the number of houses that have been
built on the property, that the good señora herself failed to recognize
very much of it, which is all natural enough.

I shall mail to you today all the photographs I have, unless
the new discovery changes everything, but you will have to wait some
days yet for criticism on your memorandum and other questions (they seem
like a million) asked for in your letters and various notes. So, please
keep your shirt on in the meantime and bear in mind that I am devoting
as much time as possible to the work you mapped out for me and which
you were rather late in mailing. By this I do not mean to criticize
the delay between date of your letter and date same was actually mailed.
I mention it so that you may not get sore at me and think I have fallen
down on the job, leaving you in the lurch.

I am now FORCED to make it to Washington & Jefferson, so
will be there alright with my little better half. Will have to find
out what date it will suit Virginia to have me stop there for a minute
- before or after my return from W&J, but I will have to make both
institutions. Elida joins me in very kindest remembrances to Mrs.
Hench and your your very good self. YOU WILL BE HEARING FROM ME
AGAIN TOMORROW.
